thread.title: Northeast gears up for more blizzard conditions - CNN.com
thread.title_full: Northeast gears up for more blizzard conditions - CNN.com

author: Azadeh Ansari
title: Northeast gears up for more blizzard conditions - CNN.com
text: MUST WATCH This is what thundersnow sounds like 00:45 The rapid strengthening of a low-pressure system will give way to this, Martin said. "The storm must drop at least 24 millibars within 24 hours for this to happen." Heavy snow will pick up pace as the coastal storm moves farther southeast toward Massachusetts and Rhode Island, intensifying near Cape Cod on Monday morning, the National Weather Service said. Wind gusts of 65 miles per hour or more are expected for the coastal region. In Cape Cod, a blizzard watch is in effect until Monday as temperatures drop below freezing. Snow accumulations in the warning areas can range from 8 to 12 inches, Maine could see more. Dicey travel conditions The freezing drizzle and blustery 15-25 mile per hour winds could create dangerous travel conditions for Monday commuters, especially on untreated roads, meteorologists said. Who's ready for more #Thundersnow ? The setup looks favorable Mon morning for #MA & #RI as a coastal storm intensifies rapidly near Cape Cod! — NWS Boston (@NWSBoston) February 12, 2017 "The snow will be heavy and wet, and winds high -- so power outages and downed trees are a concern," CNN's Martin said. "It is likely schools will be canceled again." In New York City, no snow is expected on Monday, but "gusty winds over 40 mph could lead to a lot of travel troubles to start the work week," Martin said. The storm is expected to move out by Monday night. West Coast gets drenched The West Coast continues to grapple with rapid snow melt and heavy rains in the Sierra Mountains, which led to flooding in parts of Nevada and Southern California last week. In Northern California, rainfall totals reached a record high in the Bay Area, Napa Vally and Kentfield -- the National Weather Service recorded this as the "wettest winter season to date in over 100 years." Rainfall totals for North San Francisco #BayArea #Napa #Kentfield wettest winter season - to date - in over 100 years #SanRafael 2nd wettest pic.twitter.com/QzUSvXftOX — NWS Bay Area (@NWSBayArea) February 12, 2017 Heavy downpours and heavy mountain snow are expected to last through Monday morning, the National Weather Service said. CNN's Joe Sutton contributed to this report.
